III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract/Policy violation. Please
note that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not
be included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
No Technical Assistance was required.
V. CONSULTATION
No Consultation was required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period. Special Investigation 2021C0214011dated 04/27/2021 found the
facility in noncompliance for Emergency Rule 1, Prohibition of Prone Restraint, and
rule 400.4122, Staff Qualifications. A corrective action plan dated 05/19/21 was
approved that included the staff member involved termination of employment, training
for staff, and review of current staff discipline process. During quarterly unannounced
visits to the facility, they have implemented each action step within their corrective
action plan.
The facility had nine special investigations during this period under review with six
resulting in corrective action plans. The non-compliances included proper restraints
and verbal de-escalation techniques, adequate staffing on shift, mandated reporter
guidelines and proper staff supervision. The facility’s corrective action plan
compliance is monitored quarterly.
The Kentwood Campus was toured during the inspection and was very clean and in
good condition. There were no safety concerns noted during the inspection. The
medication carts were all double locked, fire extinguishers have been serviced within
the last year, fire drill logs were viewed and up to date, menus were visible for youth
and staff, and all units were orderly.
Chief Administrator Assessment:
Chief Administrator noted the struggles of staff turnover due to staff burnout, COVID,
lack of competitive pay and program realignment. This then limited the ability to take
in new youth and lowered their average census in one of the programs. Chief
1

Administrator notes all items listed in corrective action plans have been successful.
Most of these plans were resolved through staff hiring, retraining, and bolstering their
AEGIS team to provide better support to staff addressing the needs of aggressive
youth. Chief Administrator reports the program continues to focus on recruitment,
retention, and training of staff. The program also continues to be involved and
invested in upcoming initiatives such as expansion of aftercare planning, Trauma
Informed Care, Risk reduction through restraint/seclusion elimination, racial and
gender equity, the needs of SOGIE clientele and other hot topics remain the driving
force of policy and practice change.
Interviews:
Staff and youth interviews were conducted during the inspection and no issues or
concerns were raised. The youth all reported feeling safe and had positive
relationships with staff members. The staff all reported feeling supported by direct
supervisors as well as administration.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract and policy. It is
recommended that the facility continue on their regular license.
